Title: Linking forum posts - classical-HW-001-6-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: can I repeat chords in the middle of a progression
Input.posts:
A progression like I-IV-V-I is standard and allowed. The first chord can be repeated, I-I-I-IV-V-I. But can I repeat chords within the progression? Is something like this allowed, especially with inversions => I-I64-IV-IV6-V-V6-I
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Nick So are you saying that you want to do this: I-IV-V-I-I-IV-V-I, in 8 bars? I'm sure you can, but that would mean missed opportunity to expand this basic progression into something else. You can develop this basic chord progression though the use of diatonic and chromatic substitutions as well as adding in secondary dominants and such. With regard to cadence, note that cadence always happen at the end of a phrase, and there is a sense of closure/half closure to it. So as long as V-I or other cadence-like chords that occur in the middle of a phrase with no sense of closure through breaks or a sustained note, it is not a cadence.

Input.threadtitle: Final scoring/Peer Assessments- How are they weighed?
Input.posts:
Thanks Jan. I've picked up your points from forum posts already. I'm curious about specifics like the pieces' structure is worth 20 points etc. This is the only graded assignment and it would be useful to know how it will be graded by peers. I wish this information was available before we have to assess each other's pieces!
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
While you can't see the points for each question in the peer evaluation, you can see the questions.  (I don't have a way to make the drop down menus visible so that you could see them.)  As you can see, the peer evaluation questions ask only if the requested features of the assignment are present.  So, is it in one of the acceptable meters, is it within the length requirement, does it have an acceptable instrumentation, etc.  If one follows the instructions of the assignment, one will do very well.  If you forget sometime or make a mistake, you'll have points deducted.  For instance, if you write for solo piano instead of piano and non-transposing instrument, then you lose some points, not all point. The last question asks the assessor to give qualitative feedback.  This carries no points, so the assessor has no ability to decide something very subjective.  Only highly objective things - like is there a PAC in the piece - count toward the grade.  You might put the PAC in an undesirable place and the assessor might comment on that in their qualitative feedback, but you won't be docked points for it. Hope that helps clear things up.
